newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean president's son indicted for bribery.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean president's son indicted for bribery.

text.p: South Korean President Kim Young-sam's second son was formally charged on Thursday with taking kickbacks worth $3.6 million and evading taxes, prosecution officials said.
Kim Hyun-chul was arrested last month, dealing what many believe was a mortal blow to his father's credibility.
Under Korean law, Kim could be jailed for life for tax evasion. The maximum prison sentence for bribery is five years.

According to the charges, the younger Kim -- nicknamed the "crown prince" -- took his first kickback in March 1993, the month after his father came to office. It is alleged he accepted money to secure a cable television licence.
Since then, he received a total of 6.61 billion won ($7.4 million) from businessmen, 3.22 billion in the form of bribes, the charges allege.

He also was accused of pocketing kickbacks for help in securing a road-building contract, and on one occasion to influence a court judgment during the corruption trial of former president Roh Tae-woo.
The indictment said the younger Kim evaded taxes of 1.48 billion won on the gifts from businessmen, hiding the money in accounts using borrowed names.

One of the president's first acts on taking power was to abolish false-name accounts to flush into the open vast sums of black money squirrelled away during decades of corrupt rule by military-backed government.
That move led to the arrest and jailing of Roh, and another former president, Chun Doo Hwan.
"This is not the end of our investigation," senior prosecutor Shim Je-ryoon told reporters.

Shim said there were lingering suspicions over Kim Hyun-chul's links to a loans-for-kickbacks scandal involving Hanbo Steel, which collapsed in January. A court last week jailed the founder of Hanbo, key presidential aides, politicians and top bankers for their roles in the affair.
Prosecutors had previously said they could find no connection between Hanbo and the junior Kim. But Shim said: "If new evidence emerges, we will pursue the investigation."
Opposition parties allege the president's 1992 election campaign was partly financed by Hanbo, and that after massive overspending, unused election funds were laundered by Kim Hyun-chul.

Adding weight to those allegations, state prosecutors on Thursday also indicted a former top intelligence official, Kim Ki-sup. Shim said Kim Ki-sup managed seven billion won for his close friend, the president's son, and the money may be political funds.
"We cannot call it an election fund because we cannot confirm where the money came from and for whom it was intended," said Shim.
Kim Ki-sup was charged with receiving 150 million won in bribes to help obtain a cable television licence.
Shim said the prosecution found no hard evidence that Kim Ki-sup leaked top security information to Kim Hyun-chul.

President Kim's refusal to reveal details of his campaign spending has sparked public outrage and gave fresh impetus to a leftwing student organisation, which organised violent campus agitation starting last Friday.
One riot policeman died last Monday during rioting, and on Wednesday leftwing students admitted beating a man they suspected was a police informant. The man subsequently died.
Hundreds of riot police and students have also been injured in the trouble.
